lesson_title: In the Classroom: Talking at School
objectives: Learn to use simple English phrases to talk in the classroom.
Understand and respond to common instructions given by teachers.
Learn the names of important things, places, and tools found at school.

topics.title: 1. Talking to Your Teacher and Friends

sections.text: When you want to do something, or go somewhere during class, it's polite to ask for permission. We use 'May I...' to ask.

examples.label: To enter
examples.value: May I come in?

examples.label: To leave
examples.value: May I go out?

examples.label: To use something
examples.value: May I use your pen?

examples.label: To ask a question
examples.value: May I ask a question?

examples.label: To sharpen pencil
examples.value: May I sharpen my pencil?

usage_examples: Teacher, **may I come in**? I am late.
Sir, **may I go out** to drink water?
Friend, **may I use your ruler** for a moment?
Madam, **may I answer the question**?
Always ask for permission before leaving the classroom.
**May I sit down** now?
It is dark. **May I switch on the light**?
Sir, **may I ask a question** about this topic?
My pencil is broken. **May I sharpen it**?
**May I go to the restroom**?
It is cold. **May I close the window**?
**May I borrow your eraser**?
I have finished my work. **May I go out to play**?
**May I submit my notebook**, sir?
**May I clean the blackboard**?

subtopics.title: 1.2. Asking for Help or When You Don't Understand

sections.text: It's good to ask for help if you don't understand something or need assistance. Don't be afraid to ask your teacher or a friend.

examples.label: Asking to repeat
examples.value: Can you repeat that, please?

examples.label: Not understanding
examples.value: I didn't understand, please explain.

examples.label: Asking for help with task
examples.value: Can you help me with this sum?

examples.label: Having a doubt
examples.value: I have a doubt.

examples.label: Asking for meaning
examples.value: What does this word mean?

usage_examples: Sir, **I didn't understand** the last sentence, **please explain** again.
Teacher, **can you repeat that**, please? I didn't hear clearly.
Friend, **can you help me** with this homework?
I am confused, **please explain** this diagram.
It's good to ask for help if you are stuck.
Excuse me, teacher, **I have a doubt** in this question.
**What does 'agriculture' mean**?
**Can you speak a little louder**, please?
I cannot see the board. **Can you write bigger**?
Ram, **can you help me find my book**?
I am sorry, **I do not know the answer**.
**How do you spell 'beautiful'**?
**Which page are we on**?
**Please help me** lift this desk.
I am not sure how to do this. **Please show me**.

subtopics.title: 1.3. Responding to the Teacher or Others

sections.text: When your teacher asks you something, or gives an instruction, you should respond clearly. Simple 'Yes, sir/madam' or 'No, sir/madam' is often enough. For instructions, show you understand by doing the action or saying 'Okay'.

examples.label: Agreeing
examples.value: Yes, sir.

examples.label: Understanding
examples.value: Okay, teacher.

examples.label: Confirming done
examples.value: Yes, I have finished.

examples.label: Disagreeing
examples.value: No, madam.

examples.label: Not knowing
examples.value: I don't know.

usage_examples: Teacher: 'Have you written your name?' Student: '**Yes, sir**.'
Teacher: 'Open your books.' Student: '**Okay, teacher**.'
Teacher: 'Can you read?' Student: '**Yes, madam**, I can read.'
If you understood, say '**Okay**'.
When asked a question, give a clear **yes or no** answer.
Teacher: 'Is this clear?' Student: '**Yes, it is**.'
Teacher: 'Bring your notebook.' Student: '**Okay, sir**.'
Teacher: 'Do you have a pencil?' Student: '**No, madam, I forgot**.'
Teacher: 'What is the capital of India?' Student: '**I don't know, sir**.'
Teacher: 'Let's start the lesson.' Student: '**Yes, teacher**.'
When your friend asks for help, you can say, '**Of course**.'
Teacher: 'Show me your homework.' Student: '**Here it is, madam**.'
If you are finished with your work, say, '**I am done**.'
Teacher: 'Be quiet.' Student: '**Okay, madam**.'
Teacher: 'Who broke the chalk?' Student: '**I am sorry, it was me**.'

topics.title: 2. Things We Use in the Classroom

sections.text: These are the main tools you use every day for writing, drawing, and preparing your schoolwork.

examples.label: Pen
examples.value: A tool for writing with ink.

examples.label: Pencil
examples.value: A tool for writing and drawing using graphite. You can erase its marks.

examples.label: Notebook
examples.value: A book with blank pages where you write notes and do exercises.

examples.label: Eraser
examples.value: A small rubber tool used to remove pencil marks from paper.

examples.label: Ruler
examples.value: A straight tool, usually with numbers, for drawing straight lines and measuring.

examples.label: Sharpener
examples.value: A tool for making a pencil's point sharp.

examples.label: Crayons
examples.value: Colored wax sticks used for drawing.

examples.label: School bag
examples.value: A bag to carry books and other school items.

usage_examples: I write my notes with a blue **pen**.
Always sharpen your **pencil** before drawing.
Write your answers in your **notebook** neatly.
Use an **eraser** to correct your mistakes.
Draw a straight line with your **ruler**.
I need a fresh **paper** for the exam.
The teacher used a **marker** on the whiteboard.
My younger sister likes to draw with **crayons**.
My **school bag** is very heavy today.
I need a **sharpener** for my pencil.
Please give me a piece of **chalk** for the blackboard.
We use **scissors** to cut paper for craft work.
I keep all my pens and pencils in a **pencil box**.
Use **glue** to stick the pictures in your scrapbook.
The teacher keeps our test **papers** on her table.

table.title: Common Stationery Items
rows: Draw a line with a ruler.
Clean the board with a duster.
Put the book in your school bag.

subtopics.title: 2.2. Furniture and Fixtures in the Classroom

sections.text: These are the fixed items and furniture in your classroom that help you sit, study, and learn comfortably.

examples.label: Desk
examples.value: A table where students sit to write and keep their books.

examples.label: Chair
examples.value: A seat with a backrest for one person.

examples.label: Blackboard
examples.value: A large dark board on the wall where the teacher writes with chalk.

examples.label: Whiteboard
examples.value: A large white board on the wall where the teacher writes with markers.

examples.label: Window
examples.value: An opening in the wall, usually with glass, to let in light and air.

examples.label: Door
examples.value: An entrance to the room.

examples.label: Cupboard
examples.value: A piece of furniture for storing things.

examples.label: Fan
examples.value: A machine on the ceiling that gives air.

usage_examples: Sit properly on your **chair** at your **desk**.
The teacher wrote new words on the **blackboard**.
We use a duster to clean the **whiteboard**.
Open the **window** for fresh air.
The **door** to our classroom is green.
The **walls** of our classroom are painted white.
Look up at the **ceiling**; there is a fan.
Our school has many **benches** in the playground.
The teacher keeps books in the **cupboard**.
There is a small **table** for the teacher.
Switch on the **light** if it's dark.
The **floor** of our classroom is clean.
Hang your bag on the **hook** behind the door.
Our classroom has a **dustbin** in the corner.
The clock on the **wall** shows the time.

table.title: Classroom Furniture and Parts
rows: The chalk is in the cupboard.

sections.text: These are the different types of books and helpful materials that we use for learning and understanding our subjects.

examples.label: Textbook
examples.value: A main book for studying a specific subject like English or Maths.

examples.label: Dictionary
examples.value: A book that gives the meaning of words, how to spell them, and how to pronounce them.

examples.label: Map
examples.value: A drawing that shows places like villages, cities, rivers, or countries.

examples.label: Chart
examples.value: A large paper or board with information, pictures, or diagrams to help explain things.

examples.label: Worksheet
examples.value: A paper with exercises or questions that students complete for practice.

examples.label: Globe
examples.value: A model of the Earth.

examples.label: Assignment
examples.value: A task given as part of a course of study.

usage_examples: Read your **textbook** for today's lesson.
If you don't know a word's meaning, look it up in the **dictionary**.
The teacher showed us the **map** of India.
We learned about animals from the **chart** on the wall.
Complete this **worksheet** for homework.
Our class scored well in the **quiz**.
The teacher gave us an **assignment** to write about our village.
The teacher is showing us the countries on the **globe**.
You can find many maps in an **atlas**.
I am reading a **storybook** from the library.
The science teacher showed us a **model** of the solar system.
Today we have a drawing **competition**.
The final **exam** is next month.
My **report card** shows my marks.
Keep all your worksheets in a **file**.

sections.text: Some schools use basic electronic equipment to help students learn better. These devices can show pictures, play sounds, or store information.

examples.label: Computer
examples.value: An electronic machine that can do many tasks, like showing information, playing games, or helping us type.

examples.label: Projector
examples.value: A machine that can show images orimages/basic/module-5/lesson-1/p videos from a computer onto a big screen or wall, so everyone can see.

examples.label: Speaker
examples.value: A device that makes sounds louder, so everyone in the room can hear clearly.

examples.label: Headphones
examples.value: Small devices worn over or in the ears to listen to sounds privately.

examples.label: Laptop
examples.value: A portable computer.

examples.label: Mouse
examples.value: A device used to control the cursor on a computer screen.

usage_examples: We use a **computer** in our school's computer lab.
The teacher uses the **projector** to show us diagrams.
The **speaker** makes the teacher's voice clear.
I use **headphones** to listen to English stories.
My father uses a **laptop** for his work.
The **monitor** shows what is on the computer.
We store our work on a **USB drive**.
We use a **keyboard** to type letters and numbers.
Use the **mouse** to click on the picture.
Our school has a smart board, which is like a touch-screen **whiteboard**.
The teacher played a video on the **television**.
Some students learn on a **tablet**.
The **internet** helps us find information.
We learned how to use a **printer** to print our work.
The **microphone** makes our voice louder during assembly.

sections.text: A school has different rooms and areas for different activities. Knowing their names helps you find your way around.

examples.label: Library
examples.value: A special room where many books are kept for students to read or borrow.

examples.label: Laboratory (Lab)
examples.value: A room with special tools and equipment for doing science experiments.

examples.label: Cafeteria
examples.value: A place in school where students can buy food or eat their lunch.

examples.label: Playground
examples.value: An open area outside the school where students play games and run around.

examples.label: Principal's office
examples.value: The room where the school principal works and meets people.

examples.label: Assembly hall
examples.value: A large hall where students and teachers gather.

examples.label: Staffroom
examples.value: A room for teachers to rest and work.

usage_examples: I like to read storybooks in the **library**.
We go to the **laboratory** for science experiments.
I eat my lunch in the school **cafeteria**.
Children play cricket in the **playground** after school.
My father went to the **Principal's office**.
The **hallway** connects all the classrooms.
The **restroom** is at the end of the corridor.
Our school has a small **garden** with flowers.
We have our morning prayer in the **assembly hall**.
The teachers are in the **staffroom**.
I hurt my knee and went to the school **clinic**.
The school **office** handles all the paperwork.
Our school **gate** is painted blue.
There are many bicycles at the **bicycle stand**.
The school **building** is very old.

sections.text: These are things we use during sports and physical education classes to play games and stay healthy.

examples.label: Ball
examples.value: A round object used in many games like football, cricket, or volleyball.

examples.label: Bat
examples.value: A stick used to hit a ball in games like cricket or baseball.

examples.label: Net
examples.value: A mesh barrier used in games like volleyball or badminton.

examples.label: Whistle
examples.value: A small device that makes a sharp sound, often used by coaches or referees.

examples.label: Uniform
examples.value: Special clothes worn by players of a team during sports.

examples.label: Racket
examples.value: A piece of equipment with a net, used to hit a shuttlecock in badminton.

examples.label: Skipping rope
examples.value: A rope used for skipping as a game or exercise.

usage_examples: Let's play with the **ball** in the playground.
He hits the ball with a **bat** in cricket.
The **net** divides the court in volleyball.
The coach blew his **whistle** to start the game.
All the players wore their team **uniforms**.
Our **coach** teaches us new games.
We use a **scoreboard** to keep track of points.
I play badminton with a **racket** and a **shuttlecock**.
My friends are playing with a **skipping rope**.
The runners stood at the **starting line**.
He won the **race** and got a **medal**.
We do warm-up **exercises** before we play.
The **goalkeeper** defends the goal post.
We use **cones** for practice drills.
The **referee** makes sure everyone follows the rules.
